trans-unit.source: Provides a mobile text writer adapter class for the WML device adapter set.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Creates a new instance of the specified class.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Adapters are usually constructed automatically by ASP.NET, and must have a default constructor.
The base writer object.
An object of the <xref href="System.Web.Mobile.MobileCapabilities"></xref> class that provides the capability information for the specific device.
The mobile page to write to.
Adds a variable to be initialized when the browser renders the form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
All references to the client identifier on the page are mapped, resulting in the same postback regardless of mapping.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.AddFormVariable%2A> method also can scramble client IDs that must be encrypted for security reasons.
Only visible controls generate variables.
The identifier for the control containing the variable to initialize.
The value to which the variable is initialized when the browser renders the form.
`true` to encrypt the identifier for the control; otherwise, `false`.
Sets or returns whether the writer is in analyze mode.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
WML rendering is done in two phases.
In the first phase, all calls to the renderer are analyzed for correctness.
In the second phase, the rendering is performed.
`true` if the writer is in analyze mode; otherwise, `false`.
Analyzes a single postback.
Called internally by the writer and inherited classes.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Override or call this method when advanced extensibility is required while extending the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter> class.

`true` to include in the post fields the information for all <xref href="System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler"></xref> interfaces in the form; `false` to include no <xref href="System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler"></xref> information.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlPostFieldType"></xref>.
Begins a custom markup section.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.BeginCustomMarkup%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.EndCustomMarkup%2A> methods allow a device adapter to create a section of custom markup elements.
Begins the given form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Use this method and the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.EndForm%2A> method when rendering a form.
The form to begin.
Returns the calculated URL required to post the form to the server.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class (writer).
`true` to indicate that the current form submits to an external URL; otherwise, `false`.
`true` to encode the URL string; otherwise, `false`.
The calculated URL required to post the form to the server.
Returns the query string to add to the URL to post the form to the server.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
The query string.
Closes any currently open character formatting tags.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
Closes an open paragraph.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
Returns the form currently being rendered.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The form currently being rendered.
Returns the default character formatting used by the device.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by inheriting classes.
The default character formatting used by the device.
Returns the default layout used by the device.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by inheriting classes.
The default layout used by the device.
Ends a custom markup section.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.BeginCustomMarkup%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.EndCustomMarkup%2A> methods allow a device adapter to create a section of custom markup elements.
Ends the current form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.BeginForm%2A> method and this method when rendering a form.
Ensures that character formatting tags corresponding to the current format have been written.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
Ensures that a `< p >` tag corresponding to the current layout has been written.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
Begins a block by using the character formatting from a specified style.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The specified style to use for formatting characters
Begins a block by using the formatting from a given style.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The style reference.
Ends a block that has been using the character formatting from a specified style.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The specified style to use for formatting characters.
Ends a block by using the formatting from a given style.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The style reference.
If breakAfter is true, a break is added after the closing style element.
The first form of the method assumes breakAfter to be `true`.
Returns whether the given string is a valid softkey label for the target device.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Adapters can use this method to determine whether a label is appropriate for a softkey.
The label to validate.
`true` if the given string is a valid softkey label for the target device; otherwise, `false`.
Maps the client ID of a control to a short name to be used in rendering on the form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
If the client identifier of a control is longer than 16 characters, ASP.NET substitutes a uniquely mapped short name.
All references to the client identifier on the page are mapped, resulting in the same postback regardless of mapping.
<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.MapClientIDToShortName%2A> can also scramble client IDs that must be encrypted for security reasons.
The client ID of a control to map.
Determines whether the client ID is encrypted.
A string representation of the client identifier of the control.
Returns the number of softkeys supported on the device.
The default value is 0.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Softkeys are special keys that the application can usually map to custom tasks.
Softkey text is displayed on the screen in the lower-left and lower-right corners.
The number of softkeys supported on the device.
Opens character formatting tags for the given format.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
An enumerated value representing the WML format to use while writing.
Whether to open bold character formatting.
Whether to open italic character formatting.
Whether to open character size formatting.
Opens a paragraph with the given layout.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
An enumerated value representing the layout to use when opening a paragraph.
Whether to open paragraph alignment formatting.
Whether to open paragraph wrapping formatting.
Returns the page associated with the device adapter.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Equivalent to calling the `Control.MobilePage`.
The page associated with the device adapter.
Indicates whether the `< br >` tag needs to be sent to the output stream.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
`true` if the `< br >` tag needs to be sent to the output stream; otherwise, false.
Analyzes a form after it is completed during the analyze phase.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
Renders the beginning of a form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
The form to begin rendering.
Begins rendering a hyperlink element.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

This call can be followed by calls to render text or by a call to the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.RenderImage%2A> method to render the hyperlink contents, followed by a call to the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.RenderEndHyperlink%2A> method.
The URL target.
Set to `true` if the URL is encoded.
The softkey text to use for the link if the mapToSoftKey parameter is set to `true`.

Set to `true` if the softkey label comes from the adapter itself (the default label, or something else that is adapter-specified, such as "Call" for a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.PhoneCall"></xref> control, rather than a softkey label explicitly specified by the application author).
Set to `true` if mapping to a softkey on the device.
Begins the rendering of a postback.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The softkey text to use for the link if the mapToSoftKey parameter is set to `true`.
Set to `true` if the softkey label comes from the adapter itself, rather than being a softkey label explicitly specified by the application author.
Set to `true` if mapping to a softkey on the device.
Begins rendering a selection list.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Either `name` or `iname` must be non-null.

This method can be followed by calls to the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.RenderSelectOption%2A> method for each option, followed by a call to the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.RenderEndSelect%2A> method to end the selection list.
The name of the control.
The name that the browser must use to submit the selected index back to the server.
The initial value.
The `Title` attribute on WML devices.
Whether to allow multiple selections.
Renders a `< do >` event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

If the control you are targeting is the current form and you want to include all the variables when posting back to the server, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlMobileTextWriter.RenderFormDoEvent%2A> method.
Called internally by the writer and inherited classes.
The type of action to render.
Maps to the type attribute of the `< do >` element.
Usually "accept" or "options".
The ID of the control targeted by the action.
When the user selects the action, a postback is generated, targeting the control specified by this ID.
The argument for the action.
The argument is included in the postback generated when the user selects the action.
The type used for arg.
The label associated with the action.
This usually appears as a softkey label on the device.
Whether to include all variables on the form when posting back to the server.
Completes rendering of a form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
Completes the rendering of a hyperlink element.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Set to `true` if a break is required after the link.
Completes the rendering of a postback.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Contains the target URL of the postback.
Contains the argument associated with the target URL.
Specifies the type of postback.
Must be a value from the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlPostFieldType"></xref> enumeration.
Contains a Boolean value indicating whether postback variables should be calculated.
Contains `true` if a line break should follow the control.
Contains `false` otherwise.
Completes rendering a selection list.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Indicates whether a break must follow the selection list.
Renders any extra cards that the writer needs to send to the browser.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Depending on the content of the form, the writer might need to send additional cards to the browser.
Called by the form adapter.
Renders a `< do >` event for the current form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer and inherited classes.
The type of action to render.
Maps to the type attribute of the <do> element.
Usually "accept" or "options".
The argument for the action.
The argument is included in the postback generated when the user selects the action.
The type used for arg.
The label associated with the action.
This usually appears as a softkey label on the device.
Renders a `< go >` action.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer or inherited classes.
The ID of the control targeted by the action.
When the user selects the action, a postback is generated, targeting the control specified by this ID.
The argument for the action.
The argument is included in the postback generated when the user selects the action.
The type used for arg.
Whether to include all variables on the form when posting back to the server.
Renders an image element.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Specifies the image URL.
Specifies an optional local image name.
Specifies text to display if the image cannot be displayed.
Set to `true` if a break is required after the image.
Renders a single option within a selection list.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The option text.
Renders a single option within a selection list.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The option text.
(Optional.) The option value.
Renders a text element.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The text string to be rendered.
Specifies whether a break must follow the element.
Specifies whether the text must be encoded.
Renders a text element.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The text string to be rendered.
Renders a text element.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The text string to be rendered.
Specifies whether a break must follow the element.
Renders a text-box element.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method can also scramble client IDs that must be encrypted for security reasons.
Identifies the control.
Specifies the initial value of the text box.
Specifies an optional WML format string.
Contains the title of the text box.
Specifies the password.
Sets the size of the string.
Specifies the maximum length of the string.
Determines whether the identifier for the control (ID) is encrypted.
Set to `true` if a break is required after the control is rendered.
Resets the character formatting.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method closes all character formatting tags, such as `< b >`, that have been opened.
Whether the writer must use an additional card for postbacks.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Called internally by the writer, and can be overridden by an inheriting class.
Whether to include any variables in the additional card.
`true` if the writer must use an additional card for postbacks; otherwise, `false`.
Writes the specified markup attribute and value to the output stream, and, if specified, writes the value encoded.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The markup attribute to write to the output stream.
The value assigned to the attribute.
`true` to encode the attribute and its assigned value; otherwise, `false`.
Writes a line break.
Encodes the specified text for the requesting device, and then writes it to the output stream.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The text string to encode and write to the output stream.
Encodes the specified URL, and then writes it to the output stream.
The URL might include parameters.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The URL string to encode and write to the output stream.
Writes a `< postfield >` element, using the provided parameters.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
There is an assumed `type` parameter that defaults to <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlPostFieldType.Normal>.
The field name.
The post field value.
Writes a < `postfield` > element, treating the value as specified by the type parameter.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The field name.
The post field value.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlPostFieldType"></xref>.
Writes a post field, treating the arg parameter as a variable name.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
You can use the short form as follows: `WritePostField(name, value, WmlPostFieldType.Normal)`.
The field name.
The variable name to write.
Writes the given text, encoding it if desired.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Encoding involves mapping characters with HTML/WML meanings to the appropriate character code.
The text to write.
If `true`, encodes the text.
Writes the given attribute, encoding the value by using WML text encoding.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Encoding involves mapping characters with HTML/WML meanings to the appropriate character code.
The name of the attribute to encode.
The value of the attribute to encode.
